Courses.Name: Concepts Studio
Courses.Desc: An introduction to the fundamental engineering methods, principles and skills, design and communication in architectural engineering. Techniques in analytical sketching, orthographic drawing, construction documentation, problem definition, and scaled model building will underlie the collaborative development of (a) small-scale design project(s). Students will become familiar with the language and anatomy of buildings, the studio environment and culture of peer evaluation and juried work critique, and the fundamental conventions of design. Introduction to report writing, documentation, and fundamental two-dimensional computer-aided design (2D CAD) software and tools. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 1A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: History of the Built Environment
Courses.Desc: A complementary studies course that provides a broad history of technology as it relates to buildings, towers, bridges, etc. Social, cultural, and economic influences on technological products will be discussed while surveying icons of architectural engineering. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: None

Courses.Name: Mechanics 1
Courses.Desc: Newtonian mechanics. Force systems; vectors, forces, and moments; equilibrium and free body diagrams. Mechanics of simple structures. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: 1A Architectural, Civil, Environmental, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Mechanics 2
Courses.Desc: Distributed forces, centroids, and moment of inertia. Introduction to foundations and fluid statics. Basic structural analysis. Plane trusses. Beam diagrams. Stress-strain-temperature relationships. Behaviour of members in tension, compression, and bending. Thin-walled pressure vessels. Friction. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 104; Level at least 1B Architectural, Civil, Environmental, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Linear Algebra
Courses.Desc: Linear systems of equations, matrices, and determinants. Introduction to the eigenvalue problem. Applications. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: 1A Architectural, Civil, Environmental, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Computational Methods
Courses.Desc: Introduction to computer programming, examples of efficient numerical algorithms for basic scientific computations. Programming and problem-solving concepts introduced in the course will be incorporated into projects involving architectural engineering applications. The language of instruction will be Matlab. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 1B Architectural, Civil, Environmental, or Geological Engineering.
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: BME 121, CHE 121, CIVE 121, ECE 150, MTE 121/GENE 121, SYDE 121

Courses.Name: Electrical Circuits and Instrumentation
Courses.Desc: Charge, current, and voltage. Voltage and current sources, resistors, capacitors, and inductors. Ohm's Law, Kirchhoff's Laws, nodal analysis, instrumentation amplifier circuits, impedance. Function and characteristics of basic electrical transducers. Resolution, precision, and accuracy. Basics of data acquisition.
Courses.Notes: [Note: Normally labs are held alternate weeks. Offered: AE 123 (S), CIVE 123 (W), ENVE 123 (S), GEOE 123 (S)]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 1B Architectural Engineering.

Courses.Name: Structural Design Studio
Courses.Desc: Development of design and communication skills through application in projects involving various building or bridge types. The role of structure in the built environment is explored, including issues of materiality and technology. Exposure to three-dimensional (3D) modelling and model building. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 100; Level at least 1B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 1B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Enclosure Design Studio
Courses.Desc: Development of design and communication expertise through studio projects involving various building enclosure types. Exposure to building enclosure materials, systems, applications, and methods of representation. Emphasis placed on critical evaluation, problem solving, and design synthesis. Introduction to industry standard three-dimensional computer-aided design (3D CAD) software. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 125; Level at least 2A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Solid Mechanics 1
Courses.Desc: Three-dimensional force systems, moments, couples, and resultants. Three-dimensional equilibrium problems. Shear stresses in beams. Plastic bending. Beam deflection. Torsion of shafts and thin-walled closed sections. Shear, bending moment, and deflection diagrams for beams. Compound stress and stress transformations. Design concepts. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 105; Level at least 2A Architectural or Civil Engineering, or Level at least 2B Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Solid Mechanics 2
Courses.Desc: Frames, arches, and suspended structures. Stress and strain transformations. Strain energy. Energy methods. Virtual work. Buckling of columns. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 204, 221; Level at least 2B Architectural or Civil Engineering, or Level at least 3A Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Advanced Calculus
Courses.Desc: Calculus of functions of several variables. Differentiation: partial derivatives of implicit and explicit functions, applications including optimizations. Integration: multiple integrals in various co-ordinate systems with applications; Vector calculus: vector fields, line integrals, surface integrals, and applications. Numerical integration and differentiation. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: MATH 118; Level at least 2A Architectural, Civil, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Differential Equations and Balance Laws
Courses.Desc: An introduction to ordinary differential equations with applications to mass and energy balance problems in engineering. Standard methods of solution of first and second order linear equations with constant coefficients. Numerical methods for solving ordinary differential equations. Partial differential equations. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 221; Level at least 2A Architectural, Environmental, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Probability and Statistics
Courses.Desc: Role of probability in architectural engineering and decision-making under uncertainty. Basic probability concepts. Probability distributions. Functions of random variables. Data analysis. Confidence intervals and hypothesis testing. Introduction to regression analysis. Introduction to design of experiments and statistical quality control. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: MATH 116; Level at least 2A Architectural or Civil Engineering.

Courses.Name: Environmental Building Systems Studio
Courses.Desc: Environmental performance of buildings studied via physical investigations, demonstrations, case studies, and design exercises with a focus on building mechanical and electrical systems and lighting. Embodied energy and life-cycle implications will be introduced. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 200; Level at least 2B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Structure and Properties of Materials
Courses.Desc: A basic course in structure, behaviour, and uses of engineering materials. Topics include monotonic and cyclic stress-strain behaviour of metals, and the mechanical properties of irons, steels, copper, and aluminum. Structure and mechanical properties of wood, masonry, cements, concrete, polymers, and fiber-reinforced polymers. Fracture, fatigue, corrosion, decay, moisture, and radiation damage functions.
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 2A Civil, Environmental, or Geological Engineering, or level at least 2B Architectural Engineering.

Courses.Name: Energy and the Environment
Courses.Desc: Fundamentals of thermodynamic analysis. Internal energy, enthalpy, and specific heats of solids, liquids, and gases. Energy transfer with heat, work, and mass flow. Energy balances for control-mass and control-volume systems. Heat engines, refrigerators, and heat pumps. Overview of selected renewable and non-renewable energy technologies, including photovoltaics. Environmental implications of energy use. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 2B Architectural, Civil, Environmental, or Geological Engineering.
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: BME 384, CHE 330, MTE 309, ENVE 279, ME 250, SYDE 381

Courses.Name: Fluid Mechanics and Thermal Sciences
Courses.Desc: An introduction to fluid mechanics and thermal sciences. Aspects of heat transfer via conduction, convection, and radiation. Fluid properties. Fluid statics. Bernoulli equation. The momentum equation and applications. Laminar and turbulent flow. Dimensionless numbers. Closed conduit flow. Pipe network analysis. Steady flow in pipes.
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: CIVE 105, 221; Level at least 2A Architectural or Civil Engineering.

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 2A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: F]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 2B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Architectural Engineering Studio 1
Courses.Desc: Comprehensive mid-sized community building design project(s) in collaboration with the School of Architecture. Integration of structure, systems, and architecture explored with case studies. Preparation of construction drawings and specifications. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 225; Level at least 3A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Building Enclosure Systems
Courses.Desc: A review of the functions of the building enclosure, and materials, systems and sub-systems used in modern building construction of new and retrofit of existing buildings. Interaction of the enclosure, mechanical systems, and structure, the importance of construction process and quality control, as well as the implications to sustainability will be considered.  [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 300

Courses.Name: Structural Analysis
Courses.Desc: Analysis of statically indeterminate structures using force and displacement methods. Influence lines for determinate and indeterminate structures. Introduction to the matrix stiffness method. Computer applications using commercial structural analysis software. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 205; Level at least 3A Architectural, Civil, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Introduction to Structural Design
Courses.Desc: Introduction to structural systems. Systems for carrying gravity and lateral loads in buildings. Structural design concepts. Analysis and design of concrete beams and one-way slabs. Design of steel beams and tension members. Comparison of steel and concrete framing systems. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 303; Level at least 3B Architectural, Civil, or Geological Engineering.

Courses.Name: Building Structural Systems
Courses.Desc: A review of different structural systems and materials with a focus on constructability, sustainability, economy, and performance. Concrete, steel, wood, masonry, and polymer materials, as well as framed, hybrid, shear wall, cable stayed, tension, and inflatable systems will be covered. The selection of systems as a function of occupancy, scale, labour, economy, geography, and climate will be introduced. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 200

Courses.Name: Architectural Engineering Studio 2
Courses.Desc: Comprehensive large multi-storey building design project(s) in collaboration with the School of Architecture. Integration of structure, systems, and architecture explored with case studies. Preparation of construction drawings and specifications. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 300; Level at least 3B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Soil Mechanics and Foundations
Courses.Desc: An introduction to soil mechanics principles including state of stress, ground water flow, consolidation and shear strength. An introduction to design of shallow and deep foundations. Earth pressure theories and design of retaining walls. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 3A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Structural Timber Design
Courses.Desc: An introduction to the behaviour of wood as an engineering material and design of timber structures based on limit states design principles. Topics include materials behaviour, selection and design of structural timber members and systems, including beams, joists, columns, connections, shearwalls, and diaphragms. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 2B Architectural Engineering or Architecture students

Courses.Name: Economics and Life Cycle Cost Analysis
Courses.Desc: Project financing, life-cycle cost analysis, time value of money, sensitivity analyses, tax, financial implications of infrastructure projects, quantitative decision-making, financial aspects of a business plan. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: MATH 116; Level at least 3B Architectural Engineering, 2B Civil Engineering, 3A Environmental or Geological Engineering

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 3A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 3B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Project Studio 1
Courses.Desc: Students undertake a group architectural engineering design project over two terms of their program. The purpose of the project is to demonstrate students' abilities to practice in their chosen area of expertise, using knowledge gained from their academic and employment experiences. Projects integrate all relevant aspects (e.g., structure, constructability, mechanical, and enclosure) within appropriate defined social, economic, environmental, political, and technical constraints. Project management and sustainability considerations will be emphasized. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 325; Level at least 4A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Building Performance Measurement Lab
Courses.Desc: Introduction to the techniques and utility of measuring building performance both during construction, during operation, and before retrofit. Stiffness, vibration, rain penetration, air leakage, heat flow, durability, solar control, acoustics, lighting, damage assessment, and energy consumption. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 280

Courses.Name: Project Studio 2
Courses.Desc: Completion of the detailed technical design for the project defined and initiated in AE 400. Complete oral presentation, written, and graphics deliverables. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 400; 4B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Building Service Systems
Courses.Desc: Heating, ventilating, cooling, filtration, plumbing, lighting, transport, data transmission, security, control, and life safety systems in buildings will be studied, in terms of function, performance, economics, construction, renovation, regulation, and sustainability. The interaction of systems, especially the environmental control systems, with the enclosures and structural systems in design and construction will be specifically considered. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: AE 279

Courses.Name: Engineering Law and Ethics
Courses.Desc: Background (Charter of Rights and Freedoms), contracts, torts (negligent malpractice), forms of carrying on business, professional practice (Professional Engineers Act, joint practice rules, professional misconduct and sexual harassment), alternate dispute resolution, construction liens, intellectual property (patents, trade marks, copyrights and industrial designs), labour relations and employment law, environmental law. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 4A Architectural Engineering.

Courses.Name: Design Intensive Special Topics in Architectural Engineering
Courses.Desc: A special topics course on design intensive advanced topics in architectural engineering is offered from time to time, when resources are available. For the current offering, inquire at the Department.
Courses.Prereqs: None

Courses.Name: Special Topics in Architectural Engineering
Courses.Desc: A special topics course on advanced topics in architectural engineering is offered from time to time, when resources are available. For the current offering, inquire at the Department.
Courses.Prereqs: None

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 4A Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Seminar
Courses.Desc: General seminar. [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: 4B Architectural Engineering

Courses.Name: Building Energy Analysis
Courses.Desc: Introduction to whole-building energy analysis. Energy auditing, benchmarking, and simulation. Review of relevant concepts in heat transfer and thermodynamics, including introductory psychrometrics. Interactive effects of building elements, systems, and occupant behaviour. Economic and environmental impacts of building energy use. [Offered: F, S]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 4A Architectural, Civil, or Environmental Engineering

Courses.Name: HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency
Courses.Desc: Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability. Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems. Constant- and variable-flow systems. Heat- and energy-recovery systems. Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps). [Offered: W]
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: Level at least 4A Architectural, Civil, or Environmental Engineering
